intro: Acacia spegazziniana, commonly known as the Spegazzini acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are usually phyllodes, and its yellow, globular flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it drought-tolerant. It has small, woody pods that contain seeds, and it plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various animals. The species is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of timber.

It thrives in sandy soils and is commonly found in savannah and scrubland ecosystems. This species is well adapted to dry climates and can withstand periods of drought. It plays an important role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species. Acacia spegazziniana is also sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value and its ability to stabilize soil in degraded areas.

It has since become naturalized in several regions, particularly in the Western Cape, where it spreads along roadsides and in disturbed soils.
